column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=Alternatively, protein or proteinaceous material may be hydrolyzed enzymatically.
#Text=Typically, the relevant protein source is first subjected to a (partial) hydrolysis with one or more suitable endoproteases.
#Text=Then, the resulting protein fragments can be degraded completely or partially into individual amino acids or dipeptides or tripeptides by the use of exopeptidases.

#Text=Alternatively, the endopeptidases and exopeptidases may function simultaneously in an enzyme mixture resulting in a similar complete or partial degradation of the protein or proteinaceous material.
#Text=A fundamental problem in the enzymatic hydrolysis of proteins and proteinaceous material is the formation of a bitter flavor due to the formation of short peptide fragments.

#Text=The bitter taste is believed to be the result of cleavage of proteins at amino acids with hydrophobic side chains, resulting in the formation of peptides with exposed hydrophobic side chains, which are typically inaccessible in proteins and longer peptides due to their tertiary structure.
#Text=In order to solve this problem, the state of the art proposes to use specific proteases to limit the degree of hydrolysis and obtain preferred terminal side-chains.
#Text=For example, U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 5,866,357 describes the use of a Glu/Asp specific protease for the preparation of hydrolysates, optionally with the use of an additional specific protease.

#Text=Furthermore, WO 98/27827, for example, proposes, for the purpose of solving the problem, using a proteolytic enzyme mixture comprising only one exopeptidase, wherein the exopeptidase is produced using rDNA techniques, and may be employed in combination with one or more suitable endopeptidases, such as Fromase.TM.
#Text=(Gist-Brocades, France) and Maxatase.TM.
#Text=(Genencor International, Belgium).
#Text=U.S.
#Text=Pat.

#Text=No. 5,532,007 discloses the use of a combination of purified enzymes, a neutral protease producible by means of a Bacillus strain and an alkaline protease producible by means of a Bacillus strain.
#Text=The reference states that raw meat is preferably treated with proteases exclusively with endo-activities for the purpose of the described invention to obtain meat hydrolysates.
#Text=Methods disclosed in WO 94/25580 employ a proteolytic enzyme preparation derived from the fungus Aspergillus oryzae (Flavorzyme.TM.) comprising a mixture of endopeptidases and exopeptidases.

#Text=Alternatively, EP 0 823 998 A2, proposes the enzymatic hydrolysis of smoked meat as the protein or proteinaceous material for the generation of a protein hydrolysate which does not taste bitter.

#Text=In this process it is preferred that only one enzyme, preferably a neutral or an alkaline protease having an endopeptidase effect, for example Pescalase (Gist Brocades), Alcalase (Novo Nordisk) or Promod 31 (Biocatalysts), be employed for the hydrolysis.
#Text=WO 89/10960 proposes the use of complex enzyme mixtures from krill to modificate protein, peptide and/or lipid constituents of biological material in industrial processes.
#Text=The enzyme compositions disclosed are prepared by incubating macerated whole Antarctic krill (Euphasia superba) at 50.degree.
#Text=C. for 20 h.
#Text=Examples of various applications are described, such as hydrolysis of fish and meat.
#Text=The krill enzyme preparations are said to contain different proteases and lipolytic enzymes, e.g. a considerable amount of phospholipases.
#Text=Such preparations do not seem to have been used on a commercial scale for the production of food-grade hydrolysates.
#Text=It should be noted that in all of these prior art references, hydrolysates are obtained by enzymatic incubation at 50 65.degree.
#Text=C.
